ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class supposedly counts as a "stats" course for premed requirements but there really isn't anything about statistics. Mostly coding (if you already know coding, you have a leg up) in MATLAB, and displaying the results (graphs, etc).
I learned basic MatLab skills and syntax. I learned the many applications of MatLab coding in research and real-life.
Learned how to code in MATLAB
I was introduced to Matlab coding in this class.
I learned how to use matlab and learned about statistics
Basic mat lab
Basic introduction to MATLAB
I learned a lot about how to code in Matlab and how to apply general coding functions (dice flips and random walks) for biomedical applications.

- basics matlab
graphing
randomized events
probability bias of randomized events
The focus on this course is MATLAB. No other forms of computation other than MATLAB. It ramps up near the end in what we do with MATLAB.
Matlab
A broad overview of programming and computational logic, with applications to biomedical and chemical research.
How to use Matlab and the basics within Biomedical computation.
In this course I learned how to use Matlab to develop complex models relating to biological processes.
modeling biological systems with MATLAB
I learned the basics of Matlab and understood more about the ways in which biomedical computation works.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Good class materials provided. But the lectures themselves are a little dry. It is possible to not pay attention in class and still do fine by just looking over the posted class codes because it seems Professor Mak is just looking at prewritten code and copying it down anyways. I really wish this course was updated and switched to python, something much more applicable (MATLAB seems to mostly be used in bio labs) in general.
This course provides a solid foundation in MatLab coding and is paced fairly. I think it could be improved by providing class review sessions prior to the exams.
The course could be improved by focusing less on the graphing parts of the class and more of the application of the code to real life.
The course was very well organized, but I wish there were more office hours available.

The material after the midterm was significantly harder than before the midterm. I think midterm one should be earlier and that material can be taught quicker. The units after the midterm should be given more time.
He has in class assignments to gauge your level of understanding which was great

Strengths: TFs and peer tutor, pretty reasonable pset difficulty level, practice exams that are exactly like the midterm/final
Weaknesses: The course escalated in difficulty that felt exponential (second half of course felt way more difficult than first). Generally dry lectures, didnt seem like live-coding was the most efficient way of teaching

I liked how the course was structured. The material was easy to follow and lead from one subject to the next for the most part, so we were always building on older material. The one thing I would say could be improved was the amount of biomedical applications as it felt like we only began to cover them more in-depth at the end of class.
preclass quiz for questions

The course lecture was kind of dull with not much to be excited about. It was easier to find myself more interested in getting the homework than sitting through the lecture. This is sort of the natural state of computing courses but it didn't help that nothing was done to make it more interesting. Despite the class being boring, it is informational.

Strengths: TAs were strong (Luke you were the best thanks so much for the help). Mak was super flexible and listened to feedback (added more exercises, posted lecture slides and other things when students would ask)

Weaknesses: Lectures were dry/slow so hard to pay attention. Definitely better in person than online. Not a lot of practice or resources outside lecture slides which were kind of hard to understand
Overall a pretty good introduction to coding!
The course is very interesting and making the final project was super cool.

not as bad as I thought it was going to be! Coming from someone with basically no coding experience, there is definitely a steep learning curve, but it is manageable if you go to office hours and work on PSETs with friends. Mak is a little monotonous as a lecturer, but the course is very organized and well-structured. TAs and peer tutors were very helpful. Exams are very fair and practice material is super helpful.
I think adding an additional TA session would be very helpful.

This course taught a variety of applicable information, especially relating to research and cellular modelling. Also, the sample codes provided in class were very useful in understanding the material and completing the homeworks.
clear and effective psets, final project was a good capstone
Definitely could use more diagrams or pictures to convey concepts. The use of text for slides can be disengaging and not the best for absorbing information in a lecture format.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Required for BME students. Not the best course to learn coding from scratch but it's doable.
Yes! Even if not a biomedical engineering major, this class teaches useful skills and ways of thinking.
Yes! If you want to come out of the class with an understanding of the matlab language I would recommend the class.
I would recommend this course. Just make sure you go to office hours and section it will help with the pset
No not really if you dont have to take it for your major there are probably easier ways to learn Matlab
yes, it is really helpful for learning how to code and do data analysis in Matlab.
Yup, very interesting coding program, very user friendly and interesting display methods
I would recommend this course to someone who is interested in life science, engineering, or computer science. It is an interesting topic, but not very appliable to many people.
Take it for BME but if not BME another computational course is probably better
Sure!
Yes, however, I would advise that they really take advantage of TAs and other people around them who already know how to use Matlab.
I would recommend this course to another student because the coding skills learned are very useful and were interesting as well.
yes, I had never done computational work and I now feel confident and more familiar
I would take only for the BME major. If you want to learn MATLAB, it is pretty easy and could learn with the built in tutorials.
